title: Will the value of announced global mergers and acquisitions (M&A) deals during the second quarter of 2017 exceed those in the second quarter of 2016?
preds: Looking at daily values of MAATGLOB Index for the quarter. There is a $65bn shortfall with 2 days to go.

Number of deals are down to 7,121 from 7,448, and the fees collected are also down across all regions as of 27 June. It is unlikely that there will be enough activity in the remaining few days to push the value over Q2 2016. https://markets.ft.com/data/league-tables/tables-and-trends/mergers-and-acquisitions
should have updated forecast more rigiourously
"When the Facts Change, I Change My Mind". Q2'17 Thomson One (source Thomson Reuters) value of announced global mergers as of today USD 688bn.
In spite of Amazon deal, backing down. Not many megadeals. It's possible small deals still get the numbers over 2016, but it might be hard with nothing above $50B or so.

Warren Leight:
Amazon buys Whole Foods for 13.7 billion, roughly equivalent to 11 shopping bags of their organic berries.

Down ticking, the proxies I'm following are running behind last years pace by 5-10%.  There are several "proposed"/in talks but no deal yet that are large (Colgate/Kraft Heiniz, Dish/Amazon, Verizon open solicitation, Whole Foods/Albertsons, Bunge/Glencore, etc) and could change this situation quickly.
Dealogic global announced M&A ranking (01. Jan - 22 May 2017) lists a value of USD 1,284bn.

"Despite an optimistic start to 2017 with the strongest January on record, the deal market faltered throughout the rest of Q1. In April, we saw more of the same. Overall deal volume was down by 530 deals on April 2016, however value inched higher with US$229.96bn worth of deals versus US$221.4bn. This volume decline came against the backdrop of political unrest that shows few signs of being resolved. Indeed, uncertainties over Brexit, the policies of the Trump administration, and the lead-up to elections in France and Germany have provided dealmakers with reason to pause. However, while deal volume is down, we are seeing an increase in megadeals and high- value acquisitions as dealmakers proceed with caution and are more selective over the transactions they choose to pursue."

https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/505436

Mergermarket lists the quarterly global M&A activity (value of deals) on page 3 since 2007. In seven out of ten years the second quarter deal value exceeded the first quarter deal value (Q2 higher betw. 10% avg. / 20% median vs Q1). Deal value of Q1'17 was 679 * 1.15 = 780, which is larger than 754 in Q2'16.

I confess I am possibly contrarian about the state of the global economy in that I think it is in better shape than many people appreciate, and I don't just say that because of the Economist's cover last week. I think, assuming trump doesn't get us into a trade war, that 2017 will be a better year for the global economy, and thus for M&A, than 2016 was. And that includes the headwinds of the Brexit.

Global M&A and IPO activity slowed in 2016 as factors such as volatility in the US stock market, growing concerns about China's economic slowdown, and dropping oil and commodity prices caused deal makers to become more cautious.

2016 was still a very good year historically for M&A and Q2 was an upper quartile like number.  Q4 seems to have been the big spike which tends to be followed by a little softer quarters.  It does appear that Q2 has been a little more volatile than other quarters.    The environment doesn't seem as robust, valuations around the world aren't cheap, cash on balance sheets is high but at this point in the credit cycle bond managers are starting to get picky, global protectionism, and political uncertainty. Trump's policy is to change the tax code to let US companies bring cash back on-shore, I think that creates a wave of mergers in US as companies have more options - question is whether the tax changes and deals happen fast enough for this question. Q2 2016 was a low period anyway though, so even if Trump's policy is not in effect, still a fairly low hurdle. In addition, if China is about to have trade problems with US, I'd expect the Chinese outbound M&A to ramp up to get as much of a stake in other potential allies as possible before the US can act.

Uncertainty over the political and economic future of the US and Europe, and the slowdown of the global economy, impeded strategic M&A in 2016. This trend is likely to continue in 2017.

- I previously forecasted 83%. 
- Since that time a few articles have come out:
https://www.forbes.com/sites/suntrust/2017/01/13/the-4-biggest-trends-in-mergers-and-acquisitions-for-2017/
https://www.google.com/amp/s/amp.ft.com/content/0e9afdce-cdb6-11e6-b8ce-b9c03770f8b1
- Both articles seem to be bullish on M&A for FY 2017, however both seem to cite the catalyst as the election of Donald Trump. Trump will likely not have enough time to enact pro-M&A policies to influence Q2 2017, so I'm somewhat discounting both articles. I'm adding 2% to my previous estimate.

Companies will want to diversify their business portfolios, become stronger where they are potentially weak, and struggling companies that are not competitive will be eager to be purchased/saved. Perfect storm for M&A deals.

Nothing substantial has changed on this front, though there may be more activity for its own sake this year

According to a Moody's survey, which included 1,000 corporate executives and private equity investors, 75% of respondents expect deal activity to increase. And transactions may be bigger, with 64% of survey respondents expecting deal sizes to increase. Divestitures may also be a major focus in 2017: 73% of survey respondents say they plan to shed businesses next year; that’s up from 48% in Moody’s M&A Trends Report of mid-year 2016. Furthermore penalty interest on high cash positions is still in place, corporate (& PE-) excess cash remains high, and the world (except US) will maintain ultra-low interest rates for 2017. Moderately increasing US rates (and slightly rising l-t rates) and hostile environment for Chinese (gov't driven) X-border-M&A are the only negative factors - not enough to contain M&A deal volume. Watch out for the Q1 Global M&A Market Review for potential adjustments...

75% (Base Rate) -- I started with Deloitte's 2016 Year End edition which says that 75% of respondents said deal activity (but not necessarily deal size) in 2017 to be higher than 2016. 
+5% - 64% of respondents in the same survey expect higher deal sizes. 
+5% - Higher divestitures will be a focus (divestitures count as M&A if divisions of companies are sold to another company).
-10% - 98% of respondents said that smaller tactical (sub-$1B) deals will be very active in 2017. 
+5% - 2016 Q2 was a slow quarter according to Bureau Van Dijk (lower base rate to compare against). Since then M&A activity in 2H 2016 increased by value (but not by transactions).
+ 2% - M&A is highly correlated to the S&P 500. The S&P 500 is currently (1/10/16) higher than it was in Q2 2016. I believe that it is 60% likely to decline from its current (1/10/2017) value of 2275 between now and Q2 2017 because valuations are high.
+1% - M&A value is denominated in USD. M&A value should increase with a weaker USD, however, I forecast that record USD rates will spur more deals to be transacted as American companies go shopping abroad. The USD is currently stronger against the EUR, GBP, MXN, CNY, and other currencies than it was in Q2 2016. The USD is currently at a 14 year high against several major currencies. I have no forecast on the USD one way or the other.
M&A activity was slow in Q2 2016. 2017 sees various spurs to action, including a Trump Presidency, uptick in the oil price and a desire to conclude certain corporate arrangements ahead of Brexit.
The reserves of companies is at an all time high. While R&D is lacklustre. The money is not of great use sat on the balance sheet. So I expect an increase in M&A.

policy uncertainty and protectionist stances likely to slow M&A activity

-Cash continued to pile up outside of US

Economic and political uncertainty in the US, UK, Germany, and France will more than likely lead to fewer deals.  Also, enhanced, public regulatory intervention will more than likely make big deals less likely.  2016 was a record year for deals falling through.  2017 may be more gun shy as a result.
One the one hand 2016 was a bad year for mergers, on the other 2017 might very well be worse. It hasn't even started yet and things seem already to get more tense.

The Trump administration will make the global environment more uncertain, which is always bad news for M&A services. Plus, tax inversions (the reason behind many big mergers in the late years) will surely be frowned upon, and conditions for them tightened, by the new US Government and Congress.
i think that an expectation of interest rate increases will catalyze deals.

Based on potential 2015 market top (currently possible retracement bounce which is allowed to go higher than top using Elliott Wave Theory).  Along with uncertainty in the political climate.  If we have a drop in the market again this January I expect the downtrend in M&A to continue to decrease, if not will be willing to revise.

The deals in the second quarter of 2016 had declined compared to a record year for the same period in 2015. From the history of global M&A figures it appears to be extremely rare that a maximum will occur in successive years. I would nonetheless adjust above 0 to accommodate liberalization and deregulation of trade and markets in 2017, through Trump. I suppose not based on actual changes rather on companies anticipating changes.

Global M&A deals generally follow an upward trend, but they have prominent peaks and valleys (reference: http://financial.thomsonreuters.com/content/dam/openweb/documents/pdf/financial/deal-making-infographic.pdf). The two previous peaks were in 2000 and 2007, and we are currently in a peak in 2016. I expect based on this trend that we will drop back down soon. My uncertainty is based on the volatility of M&A data and my ignorance of the subject.
the world has little appetite for mega deals and will move towards consolidation
Cooling global market from protectionist USA, Brexit will reduce M&A activity
fewer larger mergers rather than more smaller mergers possible, but looking toward late 2017 - 2018 for higher probability

It looks like there's a long lull after each spike (though we have only 3 so far so not much data) but so no pattern per-se since data set is small. In the two spikes that we have for reference, if Y is the year of the spike than Y+1 is lower and Y+2 is lower than Y+1. So the likelihood of 2017 being a down year (compared to 2016) is maybe slightly higher based on only those two data points? But trump being pro-business may change that? Trump is a wildcard - M&A does tend to, in the short-run, create lay-off and he has won on the platform of saving and creating jobs so not sure how that's going to play out. Decreasing the likelihood somewhat.

In the US Trump is not a fan of government regulation and no matter what he said during the campaign he will most likely not interfere in mega mergers. In Europe Brexit may slow things down. This is a tough call but I am leaning toward yes on this question.
